May 6, 2007: Fiction
THE CHILDREN OF HÚRIN, by J. R. R. Tolkien. Edited by Christopher Tolkien.
Illustrated by Alan Lee. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.) In Middle-earth, an evil lord wants
to destroy his rival’s children.
THE WOODS, by Harlan Coben. (Dutton, $26.95.) New evidence about a case of
murder and disappearance at a summer camp 20 years earlier forces a county
prosecutor to confront family secrets.
I HEARD THAT SONG BEFORE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster,
$25.95.) A woman marries a childhood acquaintance suspected of several
murders.
THE GOOD HUSBAND OF ZEBRA DRIVE, by Alexander McCall Smith.
(Pantheon, $21.95.) The eighth novel in the No. 1 Ladies’ Detective Agency
series.
NINETEEN MINUTES, by Jodi Picoult. (Atria, $26.95.) The aftermath of a high
school shooting reveals the fault lines in a small New Hampshire town.
OBSESSION, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Ballantine, $26.95.) The psychologist-
detective Alex Delaware investigates an apparent deathbed confession of murder.
FRESH DISASTERS, by Stuart Woods. (Putnam, $25.95.) Stone Barrington, the
New York cop turned lawyer, tangles with a mob boss.
KINGDOM COME, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $25.99.) The
final title in the “Left Behind” series.
SLEEPING WITH STRANGERS, by Eric Jerome Dickey. (Dutton, $24.95.) A hit
man who hopes to leave the business travels to London to escape pursuers.
THE ALIBI MAN, by Tami Hoag. (Bantam, $26.) A disgraced former policewoman
investigates a murder linked to a group of wealthy Palm Beach men.
WHITE NIGHT, by Jim Butcher. (Roc, $23.95.) Someone is killing Chicago’s minor
wizards, and the half-brother of Harry Dresden, a wizard detective, is a suspect.
THE BLUE ZONE, by Andrew Gross. (Morrow, $25.95.) A young woman searches
for her father when he disappears from the Witness Protection Program.
STEP ON A CRACK, by James Patterson and Michael Ledwidge. (Little, Brown,
$27.99.) A detective raising 10 children alone must rescue 34 high-level hostages.

Non-Fiction
EINSTEIN, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $32.) A biography based on
newly released personal letters.
PAULA DEEN: IT AIN’T ALL ABOUT THE COOKIN’, by Paula Deen with Sherry
Suib Cohen. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A memoir with recipes from the Southern
cooking impresario.
A LONG WAY GONE, by Ishmael Beah. (Sarah Crichton/Farrar, Straus & Giroux,
$22.) A former child soldier from Sierra Leone describes his drug-crazed killing
spree and his return to humanity.
WHERE HAVE ALL THE LEADERS GONE?, by Lee Iacocca. (Scribner, $25.) The
former C.E.O. of Chrysler protests the lack of political and business leadership on
issues like health care and energy policy.
THE AUDACITY OF HOPE, by Barack Obama. (Crown, $25.) The Illinois junior
senator proposes that Americans move beyond their political divisions.
HOW DOCTORS THINK, by Jerome Groopman. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.) A doctor
and New Yorker staff writer describes how doctors arrive at diagnoses.
FREAKONOMICS, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner. (Morrow, $27.95.)
A maverick scholar and a journalist apply economic theory to nearly everything.
THIS MOMENT ON EARTH, by John Kerry and Teresa Heinz Kerry. (Public
Affairs, $25.) Environmental challenges and possible solutions.
CRAZIES TO THE LEFT OF ME, WIMPS TO THE RIGHT, by Bernard Goldberg.
(HarperCollins, $25.95.) The author of “100 People Who Are Screwing Up
America” attacks liberals and accuses Republicans of betraying conservative
principles.
THE WILD TREES, by Richard Preston. (Random House, $25.95.) The people
who climb the massive California redwoods to study the complex life in their
canopies.
INFIDEL, by Ayaan Hirsi Ali. (Free Press, $26.) A memoir by the Somali-born
advocate for Muslim immigrant women.
GRACE (EVENTUALLY), by Anne Lamott. (Riverhead, $24.95.) Essays about
faith and forgiveness.
I FEEL BAD ABOUT MY NECK, by Nora Ephron. (Knopf, $19.95.) A witty look at
aging.
